perturbation.original_text: This Amendment shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of Japan.
perturbation.changed_text: Notwithstanding Article 1.1, Article 1.2 and Article 1.3 above, the Nissin Parties agree to cause each of VNBJ and VNBZ to comply with Sections 4.3.2 and 4.3.3 of the JV Agreement with respect to the indemnification or reimbursement, as applicable, of all Directors and Officers (except those individuals resigning pursuant to Section 6.2.6 of the VNBJ SPA and Section 6.2.6 of the VNBZ SPA) with respect to any Liabilities arising prior to the VNBJ Closing or the VNBZ Closing, as applicable. This Amendment shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Delaware.
perturbation.explanation: The governing law clause is moved to be placed after a paragraph that discusses the obligations of the Nissin Parties to comply with certain Sections of the JV Agreement, making it seem that the state of Delaware will govern the agreement for only this condition.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Choice of Law Principles - Enforceability and Predictability
perturbation.law_citation: Restatement (Second) of Conflict of Laws ยง 187
perturbation.law_explanation: Moving the governing law clause to a position where it appears to only apply to a specific obligation undermines the principle that the choice of law should be clear and consistently applicable to the entire contract. This contradicts the goal of ensuring enforceability and predictability by creating ambiguity as to which jurisdiction's laws govern the overall agreement.

perturbation.original_text: Notwithstanding Article 1.1, Article 1.2 and Article 1.3 above, the termination of the JV Agreement with respect to VNBJ, VNBZ or the Veoneer Parties shall not release any Veoneer Party or any Nissin Party from liability for the breach of any of its representations, warranties, covenants or agreements set forth in the JV Agreement that arise prior to the VNBJ Closing or the VNBZ Closing, as applicable.
perturbation.changed_text: Article 4.Effectiveness This Amendment shall only become effective upon the VNBJ Closing with respect to Article 1.1 and the VNBZ Closing with respect to Article 1.2, and shall terminate without any force or effect in the event that the VNBJ SPA and the VNBZ SPA are terminated in accordance with the terms thereof. Notwithstanding Article 1.1, Article 1.2 and Article 1.3 above, the termination of the JV Agreement with respect to VNBJ, VNBZ or the Veoneer Parties shall not release any Veoneer Party or any Nissin Party from liability for the breach of any of its representations, warranties, covenants or agreements set forth in the JV Agreement that arise prior to the VNBJ Closing or the VNBZ Closing, as applicable.
perturbation.explanation: The clause regarding liability for breaches is moved after the effectiveness clause, which could be misinterpreted to mean it only becomes relevant if the agreement becomes effective. This is a misinterpretation since it is about pre-existing breaches.
perturbation.law_explanation: By placing the clause concerning liability for prior breaches after the effectiveness clause, an ambiguity is created regarding when this liability applies. If a dispute arises, a court might interpret this ambiguity against the drafter of the contract, potentially limiting the liability of parties for breaches that occurred before the agreement was technically 'effective' under the effectiveness clause. This is because the placement could suggest that the liability clause is contingent on the agreement becoming effective, contradicting the intent to hold parties responsible for pre-existing breaches.

perturbation.original_text: Article 2.D&O Indemnity Notwithstanding Article 1.1, Article 1.2 and Article 1.3 above, the Nissin Parties agree to cause each of VNBJ and VNBZ to comply with Sections 4.3.2 and 4.3.3 of the JV Agreement with respect to the indemnification or reimbursement, as applicable, of all Directors and Officers (except those individuals resigning pursuant to Section 6.2.6 of the VNBJ SPA and Section 6.2.6 of the VNBZ SPA) with respect to any Liabilities arising prior to the VNBJ Closing or the VNBZ Closing, as applicable.
perturbation.changed_text: Article 1.Amendment and Termination of JV Agreement a.As of the VNBJ Closing, except as expressly set forth in this Amendment, the JV Agreement shall immediately cease to have any application or effect with respect to VNBJ, all rights and obligations with respect to VNBJ under the JV Agreement shall terminate and all references to "Company" or "Companies" in the JV Agreement (either in the body of the JV Agreement or its schedules and other attachments) shall read and be interpreted to mean VNBZ and/or ANRA except as the context otherwise requires. Article 2.D&O Indemnity Notwithstanding Article 1.1, Article 1.2 and Article 1.3 above, the Nissin Parties agree to cause each of VNBJ and VNBZ to comply with Sections 4.3.2 and 4.3.3 of the JV Agreement with respect to the indemnification or reimbursement, as applicable, of all Directors and Officers (except those individuals resigning pursuant to Section 6.2.6 of the VNBJ SPA and Section 6.2.6 of the VNBZ SPA) with respect to any Liabilities arising prior to the VNBJ Closing or the VNBZ Closing, as applicable.
perturbation.explanation: Moving the D&O Indemnity clause to the 'Amendment and Termination of JV Agreement' section implies that it only applies when JV Agreement ends and the companies are defunct. This makes it harder to enforce.
perturbation.law_citation: Delaware General Corporation Law ยง 141(e)
perturbation.law_explanation: By moving the D&O Indemnity clause, which protects directors and officers from liabilities, to a section focused on the termination of the JV Agreement, it implies this protection is only relevant during or after the termination process. This contradicts the duty of care, which requires directors and officers to act in good faith and with the care of an ordinarily prudent person in similar circumstances, throughout their tenure. The implication that indemnity is limited to the termination phase undermines the broader protection intended for D&Os while they are actively managing the company, potentially discouraging responsible risk-taking and decision-making during the operational phase. This is especially true because Delaware law emphasizes that directors' and officers' liability should be limited to promote corporate management and encourage qualified individuals to serve.
